{{about|the football field at the University of Chicago|the field at Springfield College|Stagg Field (Springfield College)}} [[File:Szilard and Hilberry.jpg|right|thumb|[[Metallurgical Laboratory|Met Lab]] scientists [[Leó Szilárd]] (right) and Norman Hilberry under a plaque commemorating [[Chicago Pile-1|CP-1]] on the West Stands of Old Stagg Field.]] '''Amos Alonzo Stagg Field''' is the name of two different [[American football|football]] fields for the [[University of Chicago]]. The earliest Stagg Field (1893-1957) is probably best remembered for its role in a landmark scientific achievement by [[Enrico Fermi]] during the [[Manhattan Project]]. The site of the first nuclear reaction received designation as a [[National Historic Landmark]] on February 18, 1965.<ref name=nhl/> On October 15, 1966, which is the day that the [[National Historic Preservation Act of 1966]] was enacted creating the [[National Register of Historic Places]], it was added to that as well.<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|version=2010a}}</ref> The site was named a [[Chicago Landmark]] on October 27, 1971.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cityofchicago.org/Landmarks/S/SiteNuclear.html|accessdate=March 31, 2007|publisher=City of Chicago Department of Planning and Development, Landmarks Division|year=2003|title=Site of the First Self-Sustaining Controlled Nuclear Chain Reaction}}</ref> A [[Henry Moore]] sculpture, ''[[Nuclear Energy (sculpture)|Nuclear Energy]]'', in a small quadrangle commemorates the location of the nuclear experiment.<ref name=nhl>[http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=204&ResourceType=Site Site of First Self-Sustaining Nuclear Reaction], NHL Database, ''National Historic Landmarks Program''. Retrieved 11 February 2007.</ref> The University's current Stagg Field is located a few blocks away and reuses one of the original gates.
==First nuclear chain reaction== {{Main article|Chicago Pile-1}} [[Chicago Pile-1]], the world's first artificial [[nuclear reactor]], was built under the west stands of Stagg Field, which was no longer used for football.<ref>{{cite book |last=Zug |first=J. |year=2003 |title=Squash, A History of the Game |pages=135–136 |publisher=[[Scribner (publisher)|Scribner]] |isbn=978-0-7432-2990-6}}</ref> The first man-made self-sustaining [[nuclear chain reaction]] occurred on December 2, 1942.
==Sports venue==
===First Stagg Field=== [[File:StaggField.JPG|thumb|right|Stagg Field in 1927 with the west stands in the foreground and the south stands (center-right) filled with spectators]] The first Stagg Field was a [[stadium]] at the [[University of Chicago]] in [[Chicago, Illinois]]. It was primarily used for [[American football|college football]] games, and was the home field of the [[Chicago Maroons football|Maroons]]. Stagg Field originally opened in 1893 as '''Marshall Field''', named after [[Marshall Field]] who donated land to the university to build the stadium.<ref name=program>"[http://athletics.uchicago.edu/football/fb-program-2006.pdf 2006 Football Program]," University of Chicago, pg. 35. Retrieved 6 April 2007.</ref> In 1913, the field was renamed Stagg Field after their famous coach [[Amos Alonzo Stagg]]. The final capacity, after several stadium expansions, was 50,000. The University of Chicago discontinued its football program after 1939 and left the [[Big Ten Conference]] in 1946. The stadium was demolished in 1957,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://chicagomaroon.com/2009/03/05/the-way-things-work-nuclear-waste/ | title = The Way Things Work: Nuclear waste | accessdate = 2012-06-18 | publisher = The Chicago Maroon}}</ref> and much of the stadium site was re-utilized as the site of [[Regenstein Library]].
In addition to Maroons football, the stadium hosted other events. These include the 1936 [[United States Olympic Trials (track and field)|US Olympic Trials for Track and Field]] held June 19–20, 1936 and the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[NCAA Men's Division I Outdoor Track and Field Championships|Men's Track and Field Championships]] in [[1921 NCAA Men's Track and Field Championships|1921]], [[1922 NCAA Men's Track and Field Championships|1922]], [[1923 NCAA Men's Track and Field Championships|1923]], [[1929 NCAA Men's Track and Field Championships|1929]], [[1930 NCAA Men's Track and Field Championships|1930]], [[1931 NCAA Men's Track and Field Championships|1931]], [[1932 NCAA Men's Track and Field Championships|1932]], [[1933 NCAA Men's Track and Field Championships|1933]], and [[1936 NCAA Men's Track and Field Championships|1936]].
[[Northwestern Wildcats football|Northwestern]] also played a number home games at Stagg Field. At the turn of the 20th century, Northwestern was unable to handle large crowds, so they hosted then-powerhouse [[Minnesota Golden Gophers football|Minnesota]] at Marshall Field for a 1901 game and a 1904 game. In 1925 (a year prior to the opening of [[Ryan Field (stadium)|Dyche Stadium]]) Northwestern again was unable to accommodate large crowds, and as a result played two games at Stagg Field. The first was a notable win over [[Michigan Wolverines football|Michigan]]. The second was an October 24 game against [[Tulane Green Wave football|Tulane]] that had originally been scheduled to be played at [[Soldier Field]] instead. Tulane won the game at Stagg Field 18-7.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hailtopurple.com/cde/homesites.html|title=Historic Sites of All NU Home Games|website= hailtopurple.com|accessdate=July 25, 2014}}</ref>
The University of Michigan fight song "[[The Victors]]" was written by Michigan music student Louis Elbel in 1898, following a 12-11 Michigan victory over the University of Chicago at Stagg Field.
===New Stagg Field=== [[File:University of Chicago July 2013 41 (Stagg Field).jpg|thumb|right|Stagg Field in 2013]] The current Stagg Field is an athletic field located several blocks to the northwest that preserves the Stagg Field name, as well as a relocated gate from the original facility. The school's current [[Division III (NCAA)|Division III]] football team uses the new field as their home. Stagg Field has a [[seating capacity]] of 1,650, and the playing surface is made of [[FieldTurf]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://athletics.uchicago.edu/visitors/visitingguide.pdf | title = University of Chicago Ratner Center Visiting Guide | accessdate = 2010-07-15 | publisher = University of Chicago, Athletics Department}}</ref>

{{Infobox college marching band | band name=The University Chicago Band | logo=[[Image:Pep band Logo small.jpg]] | school=[[The University of Chicago]] | location=[[Chicago, IL]] | conference=[[University Athletic Association|UAA]] | | founded=1898 | director=Katherine Demartini | assistant director=Zachary Grelewicz | members=18 | fight song=Wave The Flag | uniform=Red and white Ruby shirts }}
The '''University of Chicago Band''' is a [[pep band]] and a [[marching band]] (of the [[scramble band]] variety) for the [[University of Chicago]]. The Band was founded in 1898, five years after the university opened.
==History== University President William Rainey Harper organized the group in Autumn 1898.<ref>{{cite web|title= Uchicago marching band history| url= http://band.uchicago.edu/Site/History.html }}</ref> The band's first concert was held on December 16, 1898 in an auditorium in Kent Hall.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=pjnOAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA105 Books.google.com] "The military band of the university." The University of Chicago magazine, volume IX, number 3, January 1917, pages 105-112. Retrieved September 10, 2009</ref>
Amos Alonzo Stagg, football coach and head of the Athletic Department at the time, was eager for a band to support his teams. He incorporated the band into the Athletic Department and provided it with a budget for travel, equipment, and uniforms. The uniforms consisted of maroon sweaters and ties with white shirts and trousers. In cold weather, the bandsmen also wore overcoats and caps.
The band's original primary purpose was to support the football team in their matchups against other Midwestern and East Coast universities. Typical opponents of the time included such schools as Michigan, Wisconsin, Minnesota, Northwestern, and other universities known today as football powerhouses. In fact, the University of Chicago has a perfect 4-0 record against Notre Dame in football; the most recent matchup between the two schools took place in 1899.
The Band was originally called the UC Military Band, although it had no affiliation with any form of the Armed Forces at that time.<ref>{{cite web|title= UC military band| url= http://band.uchicago.edu/Site/History.html }}</ref> However, during World War I, almost every male member of the band enlisted in some branch of the federal service.<ref>{{cite web|title= Involvement in WWI| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LOMqAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA5-PA22 }}</ref> The band lived up to its name during World War II when it became a color guard military band.
With a fluctuating membership of 50 to 100 musicians, the band performed field maneuvers in the classic Big Ten style, spelling out letters and words as wells as forming pictures. However, it added its own zany twist to shows with balloons, confetti, and singing along with the more traditional elements of its performance.
The band performed at all home football games at Stagg Field, which stood on the current site of the Regenstein Library. It also travelled to at least one road game each year. In addition to performances at football games, basketball games, and other athletic events, the band put on concerts on a regular basis in Mandel Hall.
For many years, the band possessed permanent rehearsal and storage space underneath the stands of Stagg Field. In 1941 the band moved to new quarters in the basement of the Music Building at 5727 S. University Ave., currently called the Statistics and Mathematics Building.
[[Image:Whole band.jpg|left|thumb|thumb|The University of Chicago Band]] The UC Band's fate took a dramatic turn in 1939 when the University cancelled intercollegiate football. However, the organization survived as a concert band for several more years. It seems to have disappeared entirely sometime during World War II. The group reappeared in 1955 as a basketball band. Since then, the band has gone through several periods of activity and inactivity.
The band has had a number of directors throughout its history. The most famous was Harold Bachman,<ref>{{cite web|title= Harold Bachman| url= http://www.lib.umd.edu/archivesum/actions.DisplayEADDoc.do?source=/MdU.ead.scpa.0060.xml&style=ead }}</ref> a nationally renowned band leader, who served from 1935 until the band's demise sometime in the early 1940s. The current pep band does not have a professional director. Student members take the responsibility for musical and administrative leadership. The band continues to perform regularly at intercollegiate matches in football, men's basketball, and women's basketball. {{clear}}
===Big Bertha=== [[Image:Apf4-01704r.jpg|right|thumb|The University of Chicago Band With Big Bertha]]
The band's most notable and memorable feature was its bass drum. Known as [[Big Bertha (drum)|Big Bertha]], the drum measured eight feet in diameter and required a crew of six members, four to push the drum and two to beat it.<ref>{{cite web|title= Big Bertha| url= http://www.utexas.edu/friends/fun.php?which=3}}</ref> After [[Purdue University]] brought [[Purdue Big Bass Drum|its own large bass drum]] to a 1921 Chicago-Purdue football game,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.purdue.edu/UNS/html3month/020702.Matter.BBDhistory.html | title=Purdue's Big Bass Drum makes long-awaited return to Chicago | accessdate=2009-12-13 }}</ref> Big Bertha was donated in 1922 by C. D. Greenleaf, the president of C. G. Conn Company, a well-known manufacturer of instruments in Indiana. Greenleaf was a Chicago alumnus and an original member of the band. Along with the drum, he gave 100 instruments to the band, each bearing an engraved copy of the university seal. Big Bertha was so large that it could not fit through the doors of Mandel Hall; thus it could not be used during the band's indoor concerts.
The drum rested on a cart supported on airplane tires. Mr. Greenleaf sent a representative to the Chicago stockyards to select the largest steers found in the Chicago Stockyards, and had the drum built around drumheads made from their hides.<ref>{{cite web|title= Big Bertha| url= http://photofiles.lib.uchicago.edu/db.xqy?one=apf4-01703.xml}}</ref>
[[Image:Apf4-01703r.jpg|thumb|left|Close up of Big Bertha]] When the university canceled intercollegiate football in 1939,<ref>{{cite web|title= Cancellation of intercollegiate football| url=http://band.uchicago.edu/Site/History.html}}</ref> [[Big Bertha (drum)|Big Bertha]] went into seclusion for a number of years. It was hidden underneath Stagg Field, the old football stadium. Since the first nuclear reactor occurred under the stadium, Big Bertha later became contaminated by radiation from the atomic bomb research during the 1940s.<ref>{{cite web|title= Big Bertha Radiation| url=http://www.music.utexas.edu/LonghornBand/History/Bertha.aspx}}</ref> Big Bertha came out of seclusion when a movie about the life of the great John Philip Sousa was to be made and was offered a role in the film, "Stars and Stripes."<ref>{{cite web|title= Role in movie| url=http://www.music.utexas.edu/LonghornBand/History/Bertha.aspx}}</ref>
In 1955, Colonel D. Harold Byrd, a long-time benefactor of the Longhorn Band, purchased Bertha from the University of Chicago and gave it a new home in the heart of Texas. Mr. Moton Crockett, former Director of the Longhorn Band, constructed a special trailer for the storage and transportation. The permanent dwelling is in the comfort of the University of Texas at Austin's large Band Hall. Big Bertha is currently owned and used on a regular basis by [[The University of Texas Longhorn Band]]. {{clear}}
==Organization==
===Winds=== Currently, the instrumentation of the Uchicago Band is as follows: * [[Piccolo]]s * [[Flute]]s * [[Clarinet]]s * [[Alto Saxophone]]s * [[Tenor Saxophone]]s * [[Trumpet]]s * [[Mellophone]]s * [[Trombone]]s * [[Baritone horn|Baritones]] * [[Sousaphone|Tubas (Sousaphones)]]
===Percussion=== * [[Drumline]] (Includes [[Snare Drum]]s, [[Bass Drum]]s, [[Tenor Drum|Marching Quads]], [[Cymbal|Marching and Mounted Cymbals]]) * [[Cowbell (instrument)|Cowbell]] * [[Tambourine]]
===Front Ensemble=== *[[Glockenspiel]] (May sometimes be marching with the drumline.) *[[Bass guitar|Bass Guitar]]

The '''[[University of Chicago]] Contemporary Chamber Players''' (also called '''Contempo''', '''CCP''', or '''Contemporary Chamber Players of the University of Chicago''') is an [[United States|American]] ensemble dedicated to the performance of [[contemporary classical music]]. It was founded in [[Chicago]] in 1964 by the American composer [[Ralph Shapey]]. Its artistic director is the composer [[Shulamit Ran]].
The ensemble has presented the world premieres of over 80 compositions, by composers including [[Roger Sessions]], [[John Harbison]], Ralph Shapey, [[George Perle]], Shulamit Ran, and [[John Eaton (composer)|John Eaton]].
In October 2004 the group announced that, in recognition of its 40th anniversary, it would henceforth be known as "Contempo."[http://chronicle.uchicago.edu/041021/contempo-old.shtml]
A similarly named group, the [[Stony Brook Contemporary Chamber Players]], exists at the [[State University of New York at Stony Brook]].[http://naples.cc.sunysb.edu/CAS/music.nsf/pages/cchamber]
==External links== *[http://contempo.uchicago.edu/ Contemporary Chamber Players official site]

{{lutheranism}} '''Conrad Johan (John) Immanuel Bergendoff''' (December 3, 1895 –December 23, 1997) was an American [[Lutheran]] theologian and historian. He served as the fifth president of [[Augustana College (Illinois)|Augustana College]] in [[Rock Island, Illinois]] from 1935 to 1962.<ref name="augie">{{cite web|title=Conrad John Immanuel Bergendoff (1895-1997)|url=http://www.augustana.edu/x18013.xml|work=Presidents of Augustana College|publisher=Augustana College|accessdate=22 April 2014}}</ref>
== Early life == Conrad Bergendoff was born in [[Shickley, Nebraska]], to Carl August and Emma Mathilda Fahlberg Bergendoff. He spent his youth in [[Middletown, Connecticut]]. He graduated from [[Augustana College (Illinois)|Augustana College, Rock Island, Illinois]] in 1915 and earned his M.A. at the [[University of Pennsylvania]] in 1916. He returned to [[Rock Island, Illinois|Rock Island]] to complete the B. Div. degree at the [Augustana Theological Seminary. Bergendoff was ordained into the ministry of the [[Augustana Lutheran Synod]] on June 12, 1921 in [[Chicago]].<ref>"The Augustana Ministerium" (1980). Augustana Historical Society. ISBN 0-910184-28-3</ref> He pursued advanced study at Sweden's [[Uppsala University]], serving as personal secretary to Swedish Archbishop [[Nathan Söderblom]] during the Stockholm Conference on Life and Work in 1925. He earned his Ph.D. from the [[University of Chicago]] in 1928.<ref name="augie" />
== Career == Bergendoff became dean of the Augustana Theological Seminary in 1931, and was elected to succeed [[Gustav Andreen]] as president of [[Augustana College (Illinois)|Augustana College]] in 1935. He saw the college through the difficult years of the [[Great Depression]], through its separation from Augustana Theological Seminary in 1948, and into a long period of substantial growth and increasing prestige.<ref name="augie" />
Among his most notable achievements was the ecumenical spirit he engendered in American Lutherans from the late 1930s going forward. Instrumental in gathering together the myriad branches of the European immigrant Lutheran bodies, Bergendoff used his considerable influence and power within the Augustana Synod to help unite those Swedish-background churches into the United Lutheran Church in America (1962-1987), a precursor of the current [[Evangelical Lutheran Church in America]]. Bergendoff also devoted considerable attention to the ecumenical movement between major Protestant denominations, and on a more local and regional level he made many inroads towards official cooperation with leaders of conservative and reformed movements in American Judaism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://collections.carli.illinois.edu/cdm/ref/collection/npu_sahq/id/4409|title=Conrad Bergendoff (1895-1997)|publisher=Swedish-American Historical Quarterly. v.49, no.2. p. 156-158|date=April 1998|accessdate= March 25, 2016}}</ref>
==Selected works== *''The Church of the Lutheran Reformation: A Historical Survey of Lutheranism'' (Saint Louis, Concordia Pub. House, 1967) *''[[Olavus Petri]] and the ecclesiastical transformation in Sweden, 1521-1552: a study in the Swedish Reformation'' (Philadelphia, Fortress Press, 1965) * ''The Doctrine of the Church in American Lutheranism'' (Philadelphia, Muhlenberg Press, 1947)
== Recognition == In recognition for his work, Bergendoff received six honorary doctorates throughout his life, including one from Sweden's [[Uppsala University]].<ref name="wfn">{{cite web|title=Conrad J. Bergendoff died Dec. 23, 1997 in Rock Island, Ill.|url=http://archive.wfn.org/1998/01/msg00010.html|work=ELCA News Service|publisher=Worldwide Faith News|accessdate=22 April 2014}}</ref> The fine arts building at [[Augustana College (Illinois)|Augustana College]], constructed during his presidency, was named the Bergendoff Hall of Fine Arts.<ref name="wfn" /> [[The Lutheran]] noted Bergendoff as "one of the most influential people in 20th-century American Lutheranism".<ref>{{cite web|last=Boaden|first=Ann|title='We are a miracle'|url=http://www.thelutheran.org/article/article.cfm?article_id=367|work=The Lutheran|publisher=Evangelical Lutheran Church of America|accessdate=22 April 2014|date=September 1996}}</ref>
== Personal life == As a young pastor in [[Chicago]] he met and married Gertrude Elizabeth Carlson of Rockford, Illinois, the daughter of Swedish immigrants. Their children were Conrad born in 1924, Beatrice born in 1928, and Elizabeth born in 1937. Bergendoff and his wife were the grandparents to nine grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://archive.wfn.org/1998/01/msg00010.html|title=Conrad Bergendoff|publisher=ELCA News Service|date=January 1, 1998 |accessdate= March 25, 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
== Other sources == *Tredway, Thomas (2014) ''Conrad Bergendoff's Faith and Work. A Swedish-American Lutheran, 1895-1997'' (Augustana Historical Society) ISBN 978-0910184014
== External links == * Finding aid for the [http://www.augustana.edu/SpecialCollections/resources/finding%20aids/MSS5index.pdf Conrad Bergendoff papers] (1915-1985), held by Augustana Special Collections, Rock Island, Illinois.

[[Northwestern University]] | alma_mater = [[Zheijiang University|Chekiang University]] (B.Sc.)
Tsing Hua University (M.Sc.)
[[University of Chicago]] (Ph.D.) | thesis_title = Wave Mechanical Calculations in Astrophysical Interest | thesis_url = https://books.google.com/books?id=e20PKgAACAAJ | thesis_year = 1949 | doctoral_advisor = [[Otto Struve]] | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = Explorations of the [[circumstellar habitable zone]] and prerequisites of [[extraterrestrial life]] | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = [[John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation|Guggenheim Foundation]] Fellow (1951) | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | spouse = | children = }} {{Chinese|t=黃授書|s=[[wiktionary:黃|黄]][[wiktionary:授|授]][[wiktionary:書|书]]|p=Huáng Shòu-shū}} '''Su-Shu Huang''' ({{lang|zh|黃授書}}, April 16, 1915 – September 15, 1977) was a Chinese-born [[United States|American]] astrophysicist. A graduate of the [[University of Chicago]], Huang began his career with the study of the [[attenuation coefficient|continuous absorption coefficient]]s of two-[[electron]] systems, but eventually his research focus turned to the study of [[stellar atmosphere]]s, [[radiative zone|radiative transfer]], and [[binary star|binary]] and [[multiple star system]]s. In subsequent years, Huang began to cover the topic of life on [[extrasolar planet]]s and the prerequisites thereof, coining the term "[[habitable zone]]" to refer to the region around a star where planets could support liquid water at their surfaces at a 1959 conference of the [[Astronomical Society of the Pacific]].{{cite journal | jstor=40673575 | title=The Problem of Life in the Universe and the Mode of Star Formation | author=Huang, Su-Shu | journal=Publications of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific |date=October 1959 | volume=71 | issue=422 | pages=421–424 | bibcode=1959PASP...71..421H|doi = 10.1086/127417 }} == Education and career == A native of [[China]], Huang earned his master's degree at Tsing Hua University, lecturing in astronomy at that institution from 1943 to 1947 before immigrating to the United States, earning a doctorate in astronomy from the University of Chicago in 1949. After teaching astronomy at that institution for the two following years, Huang became an astronomer at the University of California, Berkeley, a position he stayed in before moving to the Goddard Space Flight Center in [[Maryland]] in 1959. Concurrent with his Goddard position, Huang was a member of [[Princeton University]]'s Institute for Advanced Study from 1960 to 1961, then a professor of astrophysics at the Catholic University of America from 1963 to 1964. In 1964, Huang became professor of physics and astronomy at Northwestern University, though he stayed at Goddard until 1965.{{cite web | url=http://findingaids.library.northwestern.edu/catalog/inu-ead-nua-archon-583 | title=Guide to the Su-Shu Huang (1915–1977) Papers | publisher=Northwestern University Library | work=Archival and Manuscript Collections | date=1944–1980 | accessdate=16 July 2013}} In his early years he studied two-electron systems, Huang later studied stellar atmospheres, [[radiative zone]]s, and the dynamics of stars in binary or multiple star systems. Huang's research into the physics of stars later led him to delineate the types of stars that could support [[extraterrestrial life]], leading to his coining of the term "habitable zone" and eventually his study of [[planetary habitability]] in a 1960 paper on the sizes of habitable planets.{{cite journal | title=The Sizes of Habitable Planets | author=Huang, Su-Shu | journal=Publications of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific | year=1960 | volume=72 | issue=429 | pages=489—493|bibcode = 1960PASP...72..489H |doi = 10.1086/127586 |jstor=40676939}} Huang's explorations into extraterrestrial life were also published in popular works, such as ''[[American Scientist]]''{{cite journal | jstor=27827376 | title=Occurrence of Life in the Universe | author=Huang, Su-Shu | journal=American Scientist |date=September 1959 | volume=47 | issue=3 | pages=397—402}} and ''[[Scientific American]]''.{{Cite journal | last1 = Huang | first1 = S. S. | title = Life Outside the Solar System | doi = 10.1038/scientificamerican0460-55 | journal = Scientific American | volume = 202 | issue = 4 | pages = 55 | year = 1960 | pmid = | pmc = }} == Later life and legacy == Late in his life, Huang made two trips to China, in 1974 and 1977. He died of a [[heart attack]] in Beijing during the latter trip, on September 15. Two years after his death, the then newly discovered [[main-belt asteroid]] [[3014 Huangsushu]] was named in his honor.{{cite web | url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=3014%20Huangsushu | title=3014 Huangsushu | publisher=Minor Planet Center | work=JPL Small-Body Database | accessdate=17 July 2013 | author=Minor Planet Center}} == References == {{Reflist}} {{extraterrestrial life}} {{astrobiology}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Huang, Su-Shu}} [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:1915 births]] [[Category:1977 deaths]] [[Category:American astrophysicists]] [[Category:Guggenheim Fellows]] [[Category:Tsinghua University faculty]] [[Category:University of Chicago]] [[Category:University of California, Berkeley faculty]] [[Category:Institute for Advanced Study visiting scholars]] [[Category:Catholic University of America faculty]] [[Category:Northwestern University faculty]] [[Category:University of Chicago alumni]] [[Category:Zhejiang University alumni]] [[Category:People from Changshu]]

{{Infobox civil conflict | title = University of Chicago sit-ins | partof = the [[African-American Civil Rights Movement (1954–68)|Civil Rights movement]] | image = Bernie-sanders-university-of-chicago-1962.png | caption = [[Bernie Sanders]] speaks to protesters, January 1962 | date = 1962 | place = [[Chicago]] , [[Illinois]] | coordinates = | causes = [[Racial segregation|Segregated]] housing | goals = [[Desegregation]] | methods = [[Sit-in]]s | status = | result = | side1 = [[University of Chicago Student Government|Student Government]]
[[Congress of Racial Equality|CORE]] | side2 = [[University of Chicago]] | side3 = | leadfigures1 = [[Bernie Sanders]] | leadfigures2 = [[George Wells Beadle]] | leadfigures3 = | howmany1 = | howmany2 = | howmany3 = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = | fatalities = | injuries = | arrests = | detentions = | charged = | fined = | casualties_label = | notes = | sidebox = }} The '''University of Chicago sit-ins''' were a series of [[Nonviolent resistance|nonviolent]] protests at the [[University of Chicago]] in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] in 1962. The protests were called to end the reported segregation of students in the university. ==Events== ===Dialogue=== According to ''[[The Chicago Maroon|Chicago Maroon]]'' managing editor Avima Ruder, a staffer at the student paper found a copy of the University budget, and "we discovered that the University owned a lot of segregated apartment buildings...It was really bizarre because our student population at that point was largely white, but there was no segregation, there weren’t separate dorms for African American students—if someone had suggested that, people would have been appalled."{{cite news |last=Muhlenkamp |first=Katherine |url=http://thecore.uchicago.edu/Summer2012/features/paper-trail.shtml |title=Aristotle Schwartz leaves. Malcolm X debates. The Chicago Seven feast. Maroon reporters were there. |work=The Core; College Magazine of the University of Chicago |date=2012 |accessdate=2015-09-10 }} Initially foregoing publishing the news, editors gave the apartment addresses to the Student Government, who reached out to the university chapter of the [[Congress of Racial Equality]] (CORE) to "conduct six test cases in which African American students attempted and failed to secure apartments in the segregated buildings." Student Government and CORE confronted President [[George Wells Beadle]] with their findings and demanded the buildings be desegregated. On January 17, 1962, the Maroon broke the story on the front page of the paper, with the headline, "UC Admits Housing Segregation." Beadle wrote a letter to the paper, agreeing that the university segregation was a problem, emphasized the University’s nondiscrimination policy and the difference between on-campus housing, which was open to all, and commercial residential properties acquired by the University, many of which had existing segregation policies. "The only issue on which there is arguable difference of opinion," Beadle wrote, "is the rate at which it is possible to move toward the agreed objective without losing more than is gained." ===Protests=== Frustrated with Beadle’s call for "planned, stable integration," CORE activist [[Bernie Sanders]] led a rally at the University of Chicago administration building to protest university president [[George Wells Beadle]]'s segregated campus housing policy. “We feel it is an intolerable situation, when Negro and white students of the university cannot live together in university owned apartments,” Sanders said at the protest. Sanders then strode into the building, along with 32 other students and camped out outside the president’s office, performing the first civil rights [[sit-in]] in Chicago history.{{cite news |last=Frizell |first=Sam |url=http://time.com/3896500/bernie-sanders-vermont-campaign-radical/ |title=The Radical Education of Bernie Sanders |work=Time Magazine |date=2015-05-26 |accessdate=2015-09-10 }}{{cite news |last=Perlstein |first=Rick |url=http://mag.uchicago.edu/law-policy-society/political-education |title=A political education |work=The University of Chicago Magazine |date=January 2015|accessdate=2015-09-10 }} From January 23 to February 5,{{cite book |authorlink=[[Clark Kerr]] |title=The Gold and the Blue: A Personal Memoir of the University of California, 1949 - 1967 |year=2001 |accessdate=2015-09-10 }} Sanders and the other civil rights protesters pressured Beadle and the university to form a commission to investigate discrimination.{{cite news |last=Craven |first=Jasper |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-bernie-sanders-university-of-chicago-met-20150826-story.html |title=Can Sanders' civil rights experience at U. of C. translate on campaign trail? |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=2015-08-26 |accessdate=2015-09-10 }} Beadle met with 300 students in the [[Ida Noyes Hall]] theater to announce that further sit-ins would be prohibited and that a committee would be formed to investigate CORE's charges of racial discrimination in University-owned buildings.{{cite web |url=https://www.lib.uchicago.edu/e/spcl/centcat/pres/pres_img38.html |title=The University of Chicago Centennial Catalog |accessdate=2015-09-10 }} ==See also== * [[Bernie Sanders presidential campaign, 2016]] * [[Free Speech Movement]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{UChicago}} {{African-American Civil Rights Movement}} {{Bernie Sanders}} [[Category:Civil rights protests in the United States]] [[Category:Bernie Sanders]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1962]] [[Category:1962 in Illinois]] [[Category:History of African-American civil rights]] [[Category:Civil disobedience]] [[Category:University of Chicago]]

{{unreferenced|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox station | style=Metra|name={{Metra header | name=59th Street/University of Chicago}} | type= | image=59 Street-UoC station.jpg | image_size=300px | image_caption=The platforms of the Metra electric station at 59th Street and University of Chicago. | address=59th & Harper Streets
[[Hyde Park, Chicago|Hyde Park]], [[Chicago|Chicago, Illinois]] | coordinates={{coord|41.7877|-87.5888|type:railwaystation_region:US-IL|display=inline,title}} | line={{Rail color box|system=Metra|line=Metra Electric}} | other='''[[Chicago Transit Authority|CTA Bus]]''' | structure= | platform=2 [[island platform]]s | levels= | tracks=4 | parking= | bicycle= | baggage_check= | passengers= | pass_year= | pass_percent= | pass_system= | opened= | closed= | rebuilt= | electrified= | ADA= | code= | owned= | zone=B | former=South Park, 59th Street-Stony Island | services= {{s-rail|title=Metra}} {{s-line|system=Metra|line=Metra Electric|previous=55th–56th–57th Street|next=63rd Street}} | mpassengers= }} '''59th Street/University of Chicago''' is a [[railway station]] serves the [[Metra Electric Line]] in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], [[United States]]. The station is on 59th street, originally the [[University of Chicago]]'s southern border, and the [[Midway Plaisance]]. Trains run between [[Millennium Station]] downtown and [[University Park, Illinois|University Park]], [[Blue Island, Illinois|Blue Island]], and the Chicago's neighborhood of [[South Chicago, Chicago|South Chicago]], the three southern branches. Before the [[57th Street (Metra)|57th Street Station]] to the immediate north was rebuilt into a major station in 2002, all express trains served 59th Street and the station had a staffed ticket window. The majority of University of Chicago and [[Hyde Park, Chicago|Hyde Park]] traffic is now served by the [[57th Street (Metra)|57th Street Station]]; only some express trains stop at 59th Street. It is more dilapidated than the modern 57th street station and there have been discussions to demolish it.{{Citation needed|date=March 2010}} These plans were confirmed in December 2015 when Metra announced its plan to close the 59th Street station and further add service to the 55th-56th-57th Street station. These plans also included adding ticket agents at 55th-56th-57th Street, Homewood, Flossmoor, and University Park.{{Citation needed|date=December 2015}} ==Bus connections== '''[[List of Chicago Transit Authority bus routes|CTA]]''' * 2 Hyde Park Express * 6 Jackson Park Express * 15 Jeffery Local * 28 Stony Island ==External links== *{{Commonscat-inline|59th Street (University of Chicago) (Metra)}} {{Metra web|Metra Electric|59TH-UP|59th Street/University of Chicago}} {{DEFAULTSORT:59th Street University of Chicago}} [[Category:Stations along Illinois Central Railroad lines]] [[Category:Metra stations in Chicago]] [[Category:University of Chicago]] [[Category:Railway stations at college campuses]] {{Chicago-railstation-stub}}

October 11, 2003 (dedicated) | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[University of Chicago]] | operator = | surface = | scoreboard = | estimated_cost = $51 million | suites = | architect = [[Cesar Pelli]] | project_manager = | structural engineer = OWP/P Structures | services engineer = | general_contractor = Walsh Construction Company, Inc., | main_contractors = | capacity = | record_attendance = | executive_suites = | dimensions = {{convert|150000|sqft|sqm}} | acreage = | tenants = [[Chicago Maroons men's basketball|University of Chicago men's basketball]]

University of Chicago Athletics Department }} The '''Gerald Ratner Athletics Center''' is a $51 million athletics facility within the [[University of Chicago]] campus in the [[Hyde Park, Chicago|Hyde Park]] [[Community areas of Chicago|community area]] on the [[South Side (Chicago)|South Side]] of [[Chicago]], Illinois in the United States. The building was named after University of Chicago alumnus, [[Gerald Ratner (lawyer)|Gerald Ratner]].{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagobusiness.com/article/20140620/NEWS04/130909947/lawyer-gerald-ratner-dies-at-100-crown-family-adviser-u-of-c-donor# |title=Crain's Chicago Business : Subscription Center |publisher=Chicagobusiness.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-20}} The architect of this suspension structure that is supported by [[Wikt:mast|mast]]s, [[cable]]s and [[counterweight]]s was [[César Pelli]], who is best known as the architect of the [[Petronas Towers]]. The Ratner Athletics Center was approved for use in September 2003. The facility includes, among other things: a competition [[gym]]nasium, a multilevel fitness facility, an Olympic-sized [[swimming pool]], a multipurpose [[dance studio]], meeting room space, and athletic department offices. It serves as home to several of the university's athletic teams and has hosted numerous [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] [[Division III (NCAA)|Division III]] regional and [[University Athletic Association]] conference championship events. Located at the southwest corner of Ellis Avenue and 55th Street, the Ratner Center has an award-winning design that substitutes a complex external mast and [[counterweight]] system for interior support devices to allow for large open-space areas inside the building. Cesar Pelli & Associates Inc. was credited as the design architect and OWP/P was the architect of record.{{cite web|url=http://www.risatech.com/showcase/msc/EAE2004/EAEAwards_RatnerAthleticsCenter.pdf|title=Gerald Ratner Athletics Center|accessdate=2010-05-02|work=[[Modern Steel Construction]]|date=April 2004}} ==History== A ceremonial groundbreaking was held for the Ratner Center on October 28, 2000. The Ratner Center opened to the public on September 29, 2003, although it was not officially dedicated until [[homecoming]] weekend on October 11. The building, which represented a collaboration between Cesar Pelli & Associates and Chicago's OWP/P, was the first new athletic facility on the University of Chicago campus in 68 years.{{cite news|url=http://chronicle.uchicago.edu/031009/ratner-arch.shtml|title=Art of architecture expressed in new Ratner Center |accessdate=2010-05-02|date=2003-10-09|work=[[Chicago Chronicle]]|volume=3|issue=2|author=Schuler, Peter}} It was a part of a $500 million University-wide capital improvement plan that occurred between 1999 and 2005. Part of the plan included the Pelli-designed parking structure across the street from the Athletics Center.{{cite book|title=AIA Guide To Chicago|edition=2nd|editor=Sinkevitch, Alice|year=2004|publisher=[[Harcourt Books]]|page=450}} The parking structure is named the Gerald Ratner Athletics Center Parking Structure.{{cite web|url=http://www3.owpp.com/content.cfm/uc_ratner_parking|title=The University of Chicago - Gerald Ratner Athletics Center Parking Structure|accessdate=2010-05-02|publisher=OWP/P}} The athletic center is known for its innovative asymmetrically supported cable-stayed structural system and S-shaped roofs. It is composed of a masted building to the north containing the Myers-McLoraine Swimming Pool, a masted building to the south containing the gymnasia, and a central building containing the Bernard DelGiorno fitness center.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=MpgmzOocCmMC&pg=PA152&lpg=PA152&dq=Myers-McLoraine+Swimming+Pool#v=onepage&q=Myers-McLoraine%20Swimming%20Pool&f=false|title=Pocket guide to Chicago architecture|author=McBrien, Judith Paine|publisher=[[W. W. Norton & Company]]|isbn=978-0-393-73155-2|page=152|year=2004|accessdate=2010-07-11}} [[File:Ratner Center map.PNG|thumb|left|Map of Ratner Center on the [[University of Chicago]] campus|alt=a street map with a portion of a block designated with red borders. The map also has several large green areas designating undeveloped land.]] Ratner, [[Bachelor of Philosophy|Ph.B.]],’35, [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]],’37, contributed $15 million toward the $51 million cost. He was a [[Phi Beta Kappa]] graduate and played for the [[baseball]] team during the time that the University participated in the [[Big Ten Conference]].{{cite news|url=http://chronicle.uchicago.edu/031009/ratner-profile.shtml|title=New athletics center named after ‘Red’ Ratner, a 1930s Chicago scholar, Maroon baseball player |accessdate=2010-05-02|date=2003-10-09|work=[[Chicago Chronicle]]|volume=3|issue=2|author=Schonwald, Josh}} After graduating with a law degree, [[Order of the Coif]], he eventually founded his own law firm Gould & Ratner in 1949.{{cite web|url=http://www.gouldratner.com/attorneys-52.html|title=Gerald Ratner |accessdate=2010-05-02|publisher=Gould & Ratner LLP.|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100407142611/http://www.gouldratner.com/attorneys-52.html |archivedate=2010-04-07}} [[Helen Myers McLoraine]], also an alumnus from the 1930s, contributed in excess of $5 million to fund the swimming pool.{{cite news|url=http://chronicle.uchicago.edu/001102/athletics-center.shtml|title=Architect Pelli, donor Ratner join celebration for new athletics center|accessdate=2010-05-05|work=[[Chicago Chronicle]]|volume=20|issue=4|date=2000-11-02|author=Leovy, Jennifer}} Bernard DelGiorno — a gymnast with many degrees from the university: AB’54, AB’55, MBA’55 — has made numerous donations including a $5 million one in 2006 to fund athletic facilities as well as other infrastructure on campus. DelGiorno worked in industrial relations and personnel at a steel plant before becoming a [[stockbroker]] for [[Paine Webber]], which became a part of [[UBS Financial Services]].{{cite web|url=http://alumniandfriends.uchicago.edu/site/c.mjJXJ7MLIsE/b.4700041/k.99E9/Bernard_DelGiorno.htm|title=Bernard DelGiorno: Winner, 2007 Alumni Service Medal|accessdate=2010-05-05|publisher=The University of Chicago}}{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/chicago/columns/story?columnist=greenberg_jon&id=4585864|title=Before it was normal: The University of Chicago celebrates the 40th anniversary of the return of football|accessdate=2010-05-05|date=2009-10-21|publisher=[[ESPN]]|author=Greenberg, Jon}}{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagomaroon.com/2007/9/30/delgiorno-pimps-our-football-field|title=DelGiorno pimps our football field|accessdate=2010-05-05|date=2007-09-30|work=[[Chicago Maroon]]|author=Fratar, Kate}} ==Details== The building features the {{convert|50|m|yd|adj=on}} x {{convert|25|yd|m|adj=on}} Myers-McLoraine Swimming Pool, which can be configured with up to 20 lanes in the 25-yard dimension and nine lanes in the 50-meter dimension. The pool's configuration is flexible with a moveable [[bulkhead (partition)|bulkhead]] which allows for simultaneous activities. It also has a pair of one-meter diving boards. The pool depth ranges from {{convert|4|to|13.5|ft|m}} in the shallow end and the diving well, respectively. The {{convert|24700|sqft|m2|0|adj=on}} competition [[natatorium]] features seating for 350 spectators.{{cite web|url=http://www.owpp.com/content.cfm/the_university_of_chicago_-_gerald_ratner_athletics_center|title=The University of Chicago - Gerald Ratner Athletics Center|accessdate=2010-05-04|publisher=OWP/P}} The building also includes the Bernard DelGiorno fitness center. The DelGiorno Fitness Center facility occupies two levels of the Ratner center plus the rotunda area. In addition to a general fitness center, it includes a multipurpose dance studio; classroom and meeting room space; permanent and day lockers and locker rooms; the University of Chicago Athletics Hall of Fame; and the athletic department offices. The building also features a competition gym and auxiliary gym, both of which are available to recreational users. The competition gym, which is the southernmost building, accommodates practice and game site for varsity basketball, volleyball, and wrestling, but is convertible into two recreational courts. The auxiliary gym is multipurpose and can accommodate indoor soccer, as well as basketball, volleyball, and badminton. ==Use== The Ratner Center also serves as the home of the University of Chicago basketball, volleyball, and wrestling teams. The 1,658-seat competition gymnasium has played host to the 2004, 2007 and 2010 University Athletic Association Wrestling Championships and the 2006 NCAA Division III Great Lakes Regional Wrestling Championship.{{cite web|url=http://www.uaa.rochester.edu/Wrestling/2010_UAA_Wrestling_Results.pdf|title=2010 UAA Wrestling Championship|accessdate=2010-05-05|publisher=[[University of Rochester]]}} The building also hosted the 2009 University Athletic Association Women's Volleyball Championship.{{cite web|url=http://www.ncaa.com/sports/w-volley/recaps/110709aag.html|title=No. 3 Washington-St. Louis Falls To No. 4 Emory In UAA Championship: Washington University and Emory have met to decide 11 UAA Championships, and each of the last six|accessdate=2010-05-05|date=2009-11-07|publisher=[[NCAA.org]]}} {{Dead link|date=April 2012|bot=H3llBot}} The Myers-McLoraine Swimming Pool was the site of the 2005 University Athletic Association Swimming and Diving Championship. It also hosted swimming at the [[2006 Gay Games]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gaygameschicago.org/sports/sports.php?mgroup=Swimming|title=Gay Games VII Chicago 2006|accessdate=2010-05-05|publisher=Chicago Games, Inc.}} The center is available to University and hospital faculty, staff, alumni, and retirees as well as their spouses and children on a paid membership basis and registered students for free.{{cite web|url=http://athletics.uchicago.edu/facilities/ratner-overview.htm|title=Physical Education and Athletics: Overview|accessdate=2010-06-04|publisher=[[University of Chicago]]|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080616150245/http://athletics.uchicago.edu/facilities/ratner-overview.htm |archivedate = June 16, 2008}} {{Asof|2010}},{{cite web|url=http://athletics.uchicago.edu/physed/freshman-packet.pdf|title=Fitness and Swimming Placement Test Information|accessdate=2010-06-04|publisher=[[University of Chicago]]}} the University of Chicago is one of the few remaining universities in the United States to have a swimming requirement for its undergraduate degree program. Aside from the military service academies and a few of the [[Ivy League]] schools only a half dozen Universities had such a requirement as of 2006. The swimming pool is the location of the administration of the two-lap requirement.{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagomaroon.com/2006/5/18/to-sink-or-swim-test-must-stay |title=To sink or swim: Test must stay |accessdate=2010-05-05 |date=2006-05-18 |author=Katz, Joe |work=[[Chicago Maroon]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100107033547/http://www.chicagomaroon.com/2006/5/18/to-sink-or-swim-test-must-stay |archivedate=January 7, 2010 }} The facilities memberships are available to students as well as University and [[University of Chicago Medical Center|hospital]] faculty, staff, alumni and retirees, as well as spouses and children. Registered students' memberships are free. The building is complemented at the University by its predecessors the [[Henry Crown Field House]] and the modern incarnation of [[Stagg Field]], which will continue to augment the athletic facilities needs of the campus patrons. Features of the indoor Henry Crown Field House include a 200-meter indoor running track; [[racquetball]], [[American handball|handball]] and [[Squash (sport)|squash]] courts; multipurpose courts; a multipurpose room; and cardiovascular and weight training equipment. The Stagg Field outdoor complex includes a 400-meter track, eight [[tennis courts]], and fields for [[baseball]], [[softball]], [[American football]] and [[soccer]].{{cite news|url=http://chronicle.uchicago.edu/030925/ratner.shtml|title=Ratner will open doors to University community on Monday |volume=23|issue=1|accessdate=2010-05-05|date=2003-09-25|work=[[Chicago Chronicle]]|author=Hilbert, Dave}} ==Design== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | header = Ratner Center's Myers-McLoraine Swimming Pool | header_align = center | header_background = | footer = | footer_align = left/right/center | footer_background = | width = | image1 = 20090311 Ratner Center.jpg | width1 = 165 | alt1 = Ground-level view diagonally across an intersection of a building with several tall white poles | caption1 = | image2 = 20100507 Ratner Center pool roof and masts.JPG | width2 = 165 | alt2 = view from above of the roof of a curved roof of a building with tall white poles and various cables connecting them | caption2 = }} The construction employed {{convert|2000|ST|t LT|0|lk=on}} of steel. The {{convert|2000000|lbs|kg|0|adj=on}} roof of the gym is supported by a pair of {{convert|125|ft|m|adj=on}} steel masts. The pool's roof is supported by three masts. Each mast is composed of three {{convert|18|in|cm|0|adj=on}} diameter steel hollow structural sections (HSS) filled with high-strength concrete that are arranged in a tapered tied-column configuration. The German-import masts are united by 120 high-strength steel [[cable]]s that total approximately {{convert|6500|ft|m|0}} in length. They are inclined at a 10 [[Degree (angle)|degree]] angle from vertical.{{cite web|url=http://cedb.asce.org/cgi/WWWdisplay.cgi?0206170|title=Jet Grout Columns in Mixed Profile to Control Foundation Settlement Gerald Ratner Athletics Center|accessdate=2010-05-02|publisher=[[American Society of Civil Engineers]]}} Each tapered composite mast that supports the flattened S-shaped roof girders is supported by 15 splaying cables; 9 fore-stay cables and 6 backstay cables. During construction, the masts were filled with {{convert|10000|psi|Pa|lk=on}} cast-in-place concrete using innovative pumping techniques. Concrete counterweights totaling {{convert|2500|cuyd|m3|0}} — with some as large as {{convert|50|by|25|by|13|ft|m}} — counteract the weight of the roof from below the ground. The masts and counterweights are likened as external form-giving elements to [[flying buttress]]es in [[gothic architecture]], which predominates the campus' architecture. The building is said to interpret gothic architecture through structural [[expressionism]]. The exterior support design made the interior space more receptive to open natural lighting and more accommodating for free movement. {{multiple image | align = left | direction = horizontal | header = Ratner Center gymnasium | header_align = center | header_background = | footer = | footer_align = left/right/center | footer_background = | width = | image1 = 20071123 Ratner Center.jpg | width1 = 180 | alt1 = Ground-level view of a building with white poles sticking up from its sides and with trees in autumn colors in front of it | caption1 = | image2 = 20100507 Ratner Center gymnasium roof and masts.JPG | width2 = 165 | alt2 = View from above of a building with white poles sticking up from its sides and the cables connecting them. A taller building is in the background and a connected brick building is visible on its right. | caption2 = }} The roof design incorporated multi-level splayed cables so that the structural roof members could form a {{convert|33|in|cm|1|adj=on}} deep uniformly curved roof plane. The roof members are curved and shallow. They support 7 {{convert|2|in|cm|1|adj=on}} thick {{convert|25|ft|m|1|adj=on}} metal roof deck spans between the roof girders. The W33x169 girders are cold bent with reverse curves to multiple radii. The curved roof planes are suspended from German “full-lock” steel cables and include three outer layers of interlocking Z-shaped wires designed to minimize water infiltration and corrosion. The engineering of the masts was complicated because stability was so important to the overall design success of the suspension structure. Mast displacements could significantly alter cable length and tension and redistribute loads through the superstructure contrary to design. The key to successful design was control of the [[Foundation (engineering)|foundation]] settlement. The sites natural underlying subsurface conditions were stiff silty [[clay]] below a medium dense sand layer, which was determined to be too accommodating to settlement to host the structure. Ground improvement, consisting of triple-fluid jet grouting, was performed to reduce the compressibility of the silty clay, stiffen the sand deposit and provide a desirable shallow foundation system. This site marked the first time that these geotechnical ground improvement techniques were employed. ==Reception== The facility's engineering and design has earned it awards from the [[American Council of Engineering Companies]], the [[American Institute of Steel Construction]], and the [[Consulting Engineers Council of Illinois]].{{cite web|url=http://athletics.uchicago.edu/facilities/ratnercenter.htm|title=Gerald Ratner Athletics Center |accessdate=2010-05-02|publisher=University of Chicago Department of Physical Education & Athletics |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080516134320/http://athletics.uchicago.edu/facilities/ratnercenter.htm |archivedate = May 16, 2008}} The building earned a Merit Award in the category of new buildings in the $30 million and over category in the [[National Council of Structural Engineers Associations]] 2004 Excellence in Structural Engineering Awards program.{{cite web|url=http://www.structuremag.org/archives/2005/August+2005/Gerald-Ratner-Athletics-Center.pdf|title=Gerald Ratner Athletics Center|accessdate=2010-05-04|date=August 2005|author=Eckmann, David E.|work=[[Structure (magazine)|Structure]]|page=40}}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} The building earned the 2003 Outstanding Civil Engineering Achievement of the Year award by the [[American Society of Civil Engineers]] and the 2004 Project of the Year Overall by ''[[Midwest Construction News]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.ecslimited.com/ProjectDetail.cfm?id=56|title=University of Chicago - Gerald Ratner Athletic Center, Chicago, IL|accessdate=2010-05-05|publisher=ECS Corporate Services, LLC}} ==Notes== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * [http://athletics.uchicago.edu/facilities/facilities-ratnercenter.htm Official webpage] * [http://www.structuremag.org/archives/2005/August+2005/Gerald-Ratner-Athletics-Center.pdf ''Structure Magazine'' archived news article]{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} * [http://www.modernsteel.com/Uploads/Issues/April_2004/30728_EAE_ratner.pdf from modernsteel.com] {{coord|41.79413|N|87.60180|W|source:placeopedia|display=title}} {{Clear}} {{UChicago|campus}} {{Chicago Maroons men's basketball navbox}} {{Good article}} [[Category:Sports venues in Chicago]] [[Category:University of Chicago]] [[Category:Chicago Maroons men's basketball]] [[Category:Modernist architecture in Illinois]] [[Category:High-tech architecture]] [[Category:Suspension structures]] [[Category:Postmodern architecture in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2003]] [[Category:César Pelli buildings]] [[Category:Health clubs in the United States]]

revision.text:
The '''University of Chicago Extension Division Library School''' was one of the pioneering training programs for librarians in the [[United States]]. The library school was a section within the Extension Division's Class-Study Department.<ref name=classes>"University of Chicago library classes."</ref> It closed in 1903 after receiving controversial criticisms from the [[American Library Association]].
==History==
===Beginnings=== The University of Chicago Extension Division began offering courses in “[[Library science#19th century|library economy]]” in January 1897.<ref name=Grotzinger>Grotzinger, 1966, p. 220-4.</ref> The courses covered such topics as the history of library economy to 1870, bookbinding, and how to use libraries.<ref>University Extension Division, 1896.</ref>
For the 1897-1898 school year, the program began focusing more on library work and offered three courses: "The Modern Library Movement," "Cataloging and Classification," and "Bibliography and Reference Work."<ref>Fogg, 1897.</ref> The following year, it offered the courses "Historical and Literary Outlines of Library Economy," "Technical Methods," and "Bibliography and Reference Work."<ref name=Dixson>Dixson Papers</ref> In 1901, the course "Principles of Library Administration" was also added.<ref name=Stauffer2>Stauffer, pg. 103.</ref>
===Shift to Library Training=== By 1900, the library courses had completely transformed into a school for training librarians with [[Zella Allen Dixson]] as the instructor and director.<ref name=Stauffer>Stauffer, pg. 101.</ref> Students were required to have at least two years of college experience before being admitted into the program.<ref name=Stauffer2/> While students of any major were allowed to enroll, credits were only granted to those who were library students.<ref name=Stauffer6>Stauffer, pg. 109.</ref> Each course met once a week for a two-hour session with the entire program taking two years to complete.<ref name=Stauffer2/> The school used a learn-by-doing strategy in which students worked in the university library. There were three faculty members: Dixson, cataloger Josephine Robertson, and [[Mary E. Downey]].<ref name=Stauffer3>Stauffer, pg. 105.</ref> Despite Robertson’s requests, the library science courses never became a degree program and instead offered only a certificate to students.<ref name=Stauffer4>Stauffer, pg. 106.</ref>
===Controversy & Closure=== The [[American Library Association]]’s [[Association of College and Research Libraries|College and Reference Library Section]] sent a letter to [[University of Chicago]] President [[William Rainey Harper]] criticizing the library school.<ref name=Stauffer/> The exact criticisms were that there were no entrance requirements, only 200 hours were required to complete the program, there was only one instructor (Dixson) and she was incompetent, the program did not provide the opportunity to apply the skills being taught, and the students were promised jobs that they did not receive.<ref name=Stauffer4/> Dixson denied each of these allegations and stated her belief that information about the Extension Division and the success of the library school's graduates had been suppressed from the major professional journals of the time.<ref name=Stauffer4/> She also claimed that [[Katharine Sharp]], who had founded and directed the library school at the [[University of Illinois]] in Urbana, hated everything associated with the University of Chicago and was working with [[Melvil Dewey]] of the ALA’s College Library Section to eliminate the competition the Extension Division program created with her school.<ref name=Stauffer4/> Dixson wrote a letter to Harper reminding him that, if he decided to close down the program, it would cost the university thousands of dollars in returned tuition and cause the school’s library to lose its student workers.<ref name=Stauffer4/> Faculty member and alumna Mary E. Downey also wrote a letter defending the program. In it, she stated that she chose the University of Chicago Extension Division because it was more practical than several other library schools, including the one at the University of Illinois.<ref name=Stauffer5>Stauffer, pg. 107.</ref>
In July 1903, the ALA’s Committee on Library Training issued a report evaluating different library science programs. The committee consisted of the directors of six of the programs evaluated in the report, including Katharine Sharp of the University of Illinois.<ref name=Stauffer5/> The report incorrectly named cataloger Josephine Robertson as the director of the University of Chicago Extension Division’s library school and the training program’s sole instructor. The report went on to state that the program’s admissions requirements were inadequate and that either three years of college or an entrance examination should be required. It also criticized the school for allowing students to only partially complete the program, saying that this policy could cause confusion among potential employers who may believe that the students are all qualified graduates.<ref name=Stauffer5/>
In October 1903, Harper decided to close the Extension Division's library school. The dean of the University College received many letters of protests, including one from Mary E. Downey who was acting as President of the University of Chicago Library Students Club. Downey requested the school show loyalty to its students by keeping the program open and continuing its work.<ref name=Stauffer5/> The letters did not dissuade Harper from closing the library school.
==See also== * [[library science]] * [[Education for librarianship]] * [[University of Chicago]] * [[Zella Allen Dixson]] * [[William Rainey Harper]] * [[Melvil Dewey]] * [[Katharine Sharp]] * [[American Library Association]]

[[File:UCCCC Goldblatt entrance.JPG|thumb|Goldblatt entrance at the University of Chicago Medicine Comprehensive Cancer Center]]
The '''University of Chicago Medicine Comprehensive Cancer Center''' is a collaborative [[cancer]] research center based in [[Hyde Park, Chicago|Hyde Park]], [[Chicago]], United States. The Comprehensive Cancer Center is committed to exploring and developing innovative ways to prevent and reduce cancer's devastating effects through a collaborative research program involving 210 renowned scientists and physician scientists at or affiliated with the [[University of Chicago]].<ref>http://cancer.uchicago.edu</ref>
==History== [[File:Comprehensive cancer.jpg|thumb|right]] The Comprehensive Cancer Center was founded in 1973 as the University of Chicago Cancer Research Center, and, after earning its [[Comprehensive Cancer Center]] designation,<ref>http://www.uchospitals.edu/news/1998/19980428-uccrc-comp.html</ref> was renamed the University of Chicago Medicine Comprehensive Cancer Center.
The Comprehensive Cancer Center is one of 45 comprehensive cancer centers in the United States as designated by the [[National Cancer Institute]]<ref>http://cancercenters.cancer.gov/cancer_centers/cancer-centers-list.html</ref> of the National Institutes of Health. In 2010, ''U.S. News & World Report'' once again gave the UChicago cancer program high marks, ranking it #15 in the nation.<ref>http://health.usnews.com/best-hospitals/university-of-chicago-medical-center-6431210</ref>
The first cancer research center director was John Ultmann whose specialty was the diagnosis, staging and treatment of Hodgkin's disease and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, and the development of cancer chemotherapy.<ref>http://www.uchospitals.edu/news/2000/20001024-ultmann.html</ref> The director is Michelle Le Beau<ref>http://biomed.uchicago.edu/common/faculty/lebeau.html</ref> who accepted the position in 2004. Le Beau launched and implemented a strategic plan that helped the Comprehensive Cancer Center expand the scope of its research programs, and to launch a comprehensive community engagement program to enhance public awareness about cancer prevention, detection, treatment, and the role of genetics in cancer risk. Le Beau's work has been in therapy-related cancers.
==Scientific programs== [[File:UCCCC Knapp Center Lab.jpg|thumb|Research lab at The University of Chicago's Knapp Center for Biomedical Discovery.]]
Comprehensive Cancer Center investigators are organized into six integrated scientific programs that take advantage of resources throughout the university, the [[University of Chicago Medical Center]], and other scientific and medical communities: *Program 1: Molecular Mechanisms of Cancer *Program 2: Hematopoiesis and Hematological Malignancies *Program 3: Immunology and Cancer *Program 4: Pharmacogenomics and Experimental Therapeutics *Program 5: Advanced Imaging *Program 6: Cancer Risk and Prevention
==Clinical trials== The Comprehensive Cancer Center is involved in more than 300 cancer clinical trials<ref>http://clinicaltrials.uccrc.org/</ref>{{when|date=December 2016}} and encourages participation in the clinical trials by community oncologists and minority populations through a network of affiliated hospitals. Researchers also strive to eliminate health disparities among ethnic and social groups that compose areas surrounding the UChicago campus.
[[File:Kiar 04-25-05 9027RT.jpg|thumb|[[University of Chicago Comer Children's Hospital]]]]
==Accomplishments== The University of Chicago has been the site of extraordinary breakthroughs. Scientists are proving that transforming breakthroughs in prevention will originate from the newfound understanding of the human genome. Using systems-level science to decipher the interplay among vast networks of genes, the environment, and other factors will enable researchers to map the causes of cancer, predict cancer risks for individuals, and design personalized treatment approaches.
UChicago accomplishments include landmark prostate cancer treatment in 1939, the identification of the first chromosomal abnormality in leukemia in 1972, the 1988 discovery of the molecular mechanism by which tamoxifen blocks the effects of estrogen, and the 2008 development of a new MRI procedure that can detect early breast cancer.<ref>http://cancer.uchicago.edu/about/timeline.shtml</ref>
